introduction: Here, the GEO dataset {gse} is loaded into the notebook. Expression data was quantified as gene-level counts using the ARCHS4 pipeline (Lachmann et al., 2017), available at http://amp.pharm.mssm.edu/archs4/.
methods: Raw RNA-seq data for GEO dataset {gse} was downloaded from the SRA database (https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/geo/query/acc.cgi?acc={gse}) and quantified to gene-level counts using the ARCHS4 pipeline (Lachmann et al., 2017). Gene counts were downloaded from the ARCHS4 gene expression matrix v1.1. For more information about ARCHS4, as well as free access to the quantified gene expression matrix, visit the project home page at the following URL: http://amp.pharm.mssm.edu/archs4/download.html.
reference: Lachmann, A., Torre, D., Keenan, A.B., Jagodnik, K.M., Lee, H.J., Silverstein, M.C., Wang, L., and Ma’ayan, A. (2017). Massive Mining of Publicly Available RNA-seq Data from Human and Mouse (Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory).

introduction: Here we upload a dataset submitted by users.
methods: Dataset was user-submitted, compressed in an HDF5 data package, and uploaded to Google Cloud.

introduction: Here, we load and preview a subset of the GTEx RNA-seq dataset containing the samples selected in the notebook generation process on BioJupies.
methods: Gene-level counts were downloaded from the GTEx_Analysis_2016-01-15_v7_RNASeQCv1.1.8_gene_reads.gct.gz file available GTEx web portal (https://www.gtexportal.org/home/datasets). Metadata was downloaded and processed from the GTEx_v7_Annotations_SubjectPhenotypesDS.txt and GTEx_v7_Annotations_SampleAttributesDS.txt files.

Z-score normalization was performed by first calculating the Counts Per Million (CPM) for each RNA-seq sample, followed by a log10 transformation, and finally applying a Z-score transformation for the gene expression levels. This was performed using the `zscore` function in the `scipy.stats` Python module, available here: https://docs.scipy.org/doc/scipy/reference/generated/scipy.stats.zscore.html.

reference: Love, M.I., Huber, W., and Anders, S. (2014). Moderated estimation of fold change and dispersion for RNA-seq data with DESeq2. Genome Biology 15.
Love, M.I., Huber, W., and Anders, S. (2014). Moderated estimation of fold change and dispersion for RNA-seq data with DESeq2. Genome Biology 15.

methods: Raw counts were normalized to log10-Counts Per Million (logCPM) by dividing each column by the total sum of its counts, multiplying it by 10<sup>6</sup>, followed by the application of a log10-transform.

The gene expression signature was generated by comparing gene expression levels between the control group and the experimental group using the limma R package (Ritchie et al., Nucleic Acids Research 2015), available on Bioconductor: http://bioconductor.org/packages/release/bioc/html/limma.html.
reference: Ritchie, M.E., Phipson, B., Wu, D., Hu, Y., Law, C.W., Shi, W., and Smyth, G.K. (2015). limma powers differential expression analyses for RNA-sequencing and microarray studies. Nucleic Acids Research 43, e47–e47.

Clark, N.R., Hu, K.S., Feldmann, A.S., Kou, Y., Chen, E.Y., Duan, Q., and Ma’ayan, A. (2014). The characteristic direction: a geometrical approach to identify differentially expressed genes. BMC Bioinformatics 15, 79.
